Message.Title: Haswell effect
Message.Msg: I think we can agree from first quarter that the Gartner and IDC reports are not true reflection on the current state of the PC market. One of the biggest problem with these reports is that they do not count tablets or detachable devices in their numbers. Those devices are the hot sellers and would most likely show a different picture if they were counted. Having said that, if we assume the Gartner and IDC numbers are correct for desktops and non-detachable notebooks/ultrabooks, I find it interesting that the US numbers were extremely better than the rest of the world. Here's a quote from a zdnet article: "The silver lining from the report (if there is one) could be the U.S. market. Not only did Gartner find a 1.4 percent decline on an annual basis, but researchers also pinpointed that the market grew by 8.5 percent sequentially." What could account for such a difference (1.4% vs 11%)? Improvement in the US economy? Maybe. But I think it has more to do with the fact that new PCs with Haswell inside, as with all new PCs, start to sell in the US market first. Haswell just started shipping towards the end of the 2nd quarter and most were probably shipped to the US. This is the Haswell effect. I think we see growth in PC this year as Haswell gets shipped to the rest of the world. And we also need to take into account that Bay Trail starts to ship this quarter. IMO, Intel will have an incredible year!

Topic.Title: Haswell effect

Message.Msg: MSFT Surface systems have a detachable keyboard and are counted as tablets. 900k units in Q1. and .... PC sales spurt was attributed to WinXP upgrades by commercial buyers upgrading to Win7. Those corporate buyers using an EOL'd 12-year OS are upgrading to the 5-year old Win7 OS AND NOT because IDC got it wrong. I am amazed at how much people can say they "know for sure" when there is only "opinions" to support their theories. End of Windows XP support spurring PC sales By PATRICK SEITZ Posted 07/11/2013 05:53 PM ET Personal computer sales are getting a much-needed boost from businesses replacing their aging Windows XP machines ahead of Microsoft (MSFT) ending support for the nearly 12-year-old operating system next April. Market research firm IDC said second-quarter PC shipments were better than expected, especially in the U.S., thanks to commercial buyers upgrading their PCs to Windows 7 machines. Consumer PC buying remains weak, however, as the public continues to shun Microsoft's poorly received Windows 8 operating system and spends its money on tablets and smartphones instead. "A lot of the slack (in PC buying) was taken up by businesses rather than consumers" in Q2, IDC analyst Jay Chou told IBD Thursday. Last quarter, commercial customers accounted for 47% of PC purchases, he said. and some more ....

Message.Title: Acer Aspire S7 Jumps Aboard The Haswell Bandwagon As Well
Message.Msg: It seems that the Haswell processor is starting to get more and more popular, especially since we have caught whiff of at least two other machines – one from Lenovo, and the other from Dell, arrive with the Haswell chipset underneath the hood. Taiwanese computer manufacturer Acer does not want to miss out on the bandwagon either, where they have announced that the Acer Aspire S7 will be shipping to customers with a Haswell processor within. First spotted on Amazon, the redesigned Acer flagship S7 Ultrabook is said to come with 33% additional battery life, which would mean one is capable of enjoying up to 7 hours of juice, in addition to incorporating a high resolution 2,560×1,440 (WQHD) IPS display. The Acer Aspire S7 Ultrabook will also come with an electroluminescent backlit keyboard, WiDi connectivity, a quieter fan technology that should sit down well with those who work late into the night in bed so as not to disturb their partner, and Gorilla Glass to offer the LCD panel additional protection. From ubergizmo

Message.Title: Acer, Lenovo Unveil Intel Haswell-Based Systems
Message.Msg: Acer releases the Aspire M5-583P-6428, while Lenovo reportedly is preparing to release a new ThinkPad Ultrabook, the T440s. Acer has upgraded its M5 Series family of notebooks with a system that is powered by Intel’s new “Haswell” chips, and it appears that Lenovo may not be far behind. Acer officials on July 9 unveiled the Aspire M5-583P-6428, which includes Intel’s fourth-generation Core i5 processor and the chip maker’s Wireless Display (WiDi) technology. In addition, the new notebook has an improved sound system. For its part, Lenovo reportedly is preparing to release a new notebook, the ThinkPad T440s Ultrabook, which also will be powered by a Haswell chip. The company—the world’s second-largest PC maker, behind Hewlett-Packard—is building out a page on its Website featuring the T440s, and the partial page has been seen by such tech sites as Liliputing and Endgadget. The site reportedly does not talk about a release date for the system, but Lenovo officials apparently are aiming the 14-inch Ultrabook at business users. See more at: eweek

Message.Title: Best Buy Lands Exclusive Acer M5 Multi-Touch Notebook Running Haswell
Message.Msg: The only place you can score Acer's new M5-583P-6428 laptop is at Best Buy, where it's being offered exclusively for $700. It features a 10-point multi-touch display powered by a 4th generation Intel Core i5 4200U dual-core processor (Haswell) clocked at 1.6GHz (2.6GHz via Turbo) with 3MB of cache and Intel HD Graphics 4400 clocked at 200MHz base and 1GHz max. Like so many of today's laptops, the M5 is a svelte machine measuring less than an inch thick. It sports a new metal chassis with clean modern lines, a silver aluminum finish, "soft touch" texture on the bottom, and a backlit keyboard, a feature we love to see in an affordable Ultrabook form factor. Acer Aspire M5 Lid In addition to the components mentioned above, the M5 also features a 500GB hard drive, Intel WiDi support, built-in Wi-Fi, two USB 2.0 ports, a single USB 3.0 port, HDMI output, GbE LAN, SD card slot, four 2W speakers, Windows 8, and a 4-cell battery the company claims is good for up to 6.5 hours of run time. Acer also says that its battery can go for 1,000 cycles, lasting up to 4 years, courtesy of its PowerSmart technology. Acer Aspire M5 "The new Acer M5-583P-6428 provides consumers with a great package of leading technology at a very affordable price," said Scott Ledterman, vice president, U.S. consumer sales. "It’s a compelling solution for those wanting the latest and greatest features without breaking the bank." From hothardware

Message.Msg: I don't believe that the total number of phones in the world decreased last year. I could believe that the rate of increase is slowing, or that the replacement rate is slowing as new models come out with fewer goodies that people want. The percentage of phones that are smartphones is definitely increasing. As long as the world population increases, phone sales will increase. Until something that replaces the phone is invented.

Topic.Title: Why did Intel miss the game console market??

Message.Msg: Yes. Intel could have invested its resources into a market that was "shrinking faster than desktop PC's". "Poor leadership"? Not hardly. Game Over? Why Video-Game-Console Sales Are Plummeting By Martha C. White Feb. 11, 2013 Sales of consoles in the U.S. dropped 21% in 2012 to just over $4 billion, and figures from the manufacturers of the three top systems were lackluster over the crucial holiday season At a quick glance, it looks like it could be “game over” for the video-game-console business. Sales of consoles in the U.S. dropped 21% in 2012 to just over $4 billion, and figures from the manufacturers of the three top systems were lackluster over the crucial holiday season. When announcing its quarterly earnings last month, Microsoft said its Xbox-division revenue dropped 29%. At Sony, lower PlayStation 3 and PSP sales were responsible for a 15% drop in revenue for its video-game division. Nintendo’s next-gen console Wii U also failed to generate as much interest as originally predicted. Last month, the company said it had sold only about 3 million consoles and that it would sell a million more through March, a sharp drop from the 5.5 million it initially anticipated selling. There’s less demand for the physical games these days too. According to research company NPD Group, game sales fell from a little over $11 billion in 2011 to less than $9 billion last year. Retailer GameStop says sales of new video games over the holiday season dropped by about 5%, and sales of used games dropped by 16%. “It’s tracking to be the worst quarter the company’s ever had in the used business,” Sean McGowan, an analyst with Needham & Co., told the Wall Street Journal. Analysts blame a lot of the slump on timing. “It is a cyclical market,” says Lewis Ward, research manager of gaming at IDC. “The usual lifespan is 10 to 12 years for a console, and we are in a trough right now.” Read more: http://business.time.

Message.Title: GloFo CEO Sings the Blues
Message.Msg: SEMICON 2013 Ajit Manocha, the CEO of wafer-baker GlobalFoundries, sees plenty of choppy waters ahead for the good ship Moore's Law – and warns that navigating them will be increasingly expensive. As chip-baking processes shrink, it's getting more difficult to develop manufacturing techniques at a reasonable cost. Breakthroughs are needed even at the upcoming 14-nanometer process node, Manocha told his keynote audience at SEMICON West 2013 on Tuesday in San Francisco. "We desperately need EUV," he said, "and EUV is still not ready." Manocha didn't mention one other problem with die-stacked packaging that has also been discussed in the industry: the fact that die testing has to be improved and made more logic cell–specific – perhaps even transistor-specific – so that if you can find a hidden defect in a logic cell in one die before its packaged you won't waste the other perfectly good dies that you would have already stacked with it. Costs are also a concern due to the number of masks needed in chip manufacturing. Back in the far-distant days of 180nm process, Manocha said, 15 to 20 masks were needed in the photolithographic process of chip manufacture. At 14nm, that number has grown to 60, "plus or minus," he said. The more masks, the more complexity; the more complexity, the higher the cost. "Something goes wrong, you have to start all over again; 60 mask layers, typically 1.5 days per mask layer, 90 days gone," he said. "Product life-cycle, very short." EUV would help. A lot. From the register [Gee, does anybody on Wall Street know about ARM's fabrication crisis. With ARM bumping up against $40 again, obviously not...]

Topic.Title: Short covering started already

Message.Msg: No need. Some are required for the Inverse ETF positions (either real shots or derivative tracking). Option market maker hedging. One area would be by those holding the convertible notes. They are getting the coupons, but when the share price goes higher than their conversion price, they can short INTC since they own shares by proxy through the convertible notes. example .... SANTA CLARA, Calif., Jul 21, 2009 (BUSINESS WIRE) -- Intel Corporation today announced the pricing of its offering of $1.75 billion principal amount of 3.25 percent junior subordinated convertible debentures due 2039. The debentures were offered and sold to qualified institutional buyers pursuant to Rule 144A under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended. The sale is expected to close July 27, 2009. Intel has also granted to the initial purchasers of the debentures the right to purchase up to an additional $250 million principal amount of debentures to cover overallotments. Intel intends to seek a rating for the debentures promptly following the offering. Interest will be payable on the debentures semiannually at a rate of 3.25 percent per annum. In addition to regular interest, beginning on Aug. 1, 2019, contingent interest will accrue in certain circumstances relating to the trading price of the debentures. In certain circumstances, the debentures will be convertible into cash up to their principal amount and any conversion value above the principal amount will, at Intel's option, be settled with shares of Intel common stock or cash. The initial conversion rate for the debentures is 44.0917 shares of common stock per $1,000 principal amount of the debentures, which is equal to a conversion price of approximately $22.68 per share, representing a 20 percent conversion premium based on the closing price of Intel's common stock of $18.90 per share on July 21, 2009. The debentures mature Aug. 1, 2039.

Topic.Title: Is Samsung About to Abandon Android?

Message.Msg: The fast answer if that Samsung isn't about to abandon Android. I posted an article a week or so ago about how Samsung was putting some Tizen plans on hold for a short time . It will come out but I am speculating that the big attraction will be for cell service providers to get their own exclusive online store to sell content. 90% of Android worked with Intel from day one. Some programmers may have to rewrite some of their code to get their apps to work with Intel. Intel running Android isn't a deal breaker.

Topic.Title: Is Samsung About to Abandon Android?

Message.Msg: Samsung won't just abandon Android because it is their bread and butter right now. I think Samsung is seeking to diversify its products and include more Windows/Intel products. You see the ATIV line, tablets and a phone and an Intel equipped Galaxy tab. Samsung just sort of throws a bunch of products out there and sees what sticks. Tizen is a sideshow.

Topic.Title: Didn't Intel buy a big number of Patents from Motorolla?

Message.Msg: Maybe it's just me, but with Intel supposedly being an Intel partner, this seems like it would be a HUGE slap in the face if the Google/Motorola X phone comes out later this year with a Qualcom processor. What would this say about Intel's mobile roadmap/capabilities if they can't even talk their partner into helping them make a big splash into Mobile? This is very concerning to me as an Intel Long.

Topic.Title: Didn't Intel buy a big number of Patents from Motorolla?

Message.Msg: 11:45 AM Google (GOOG) is believed to be working on a high-end smartphone with Motorola, codenamed X Phone, that is expected debut this May. Initial reports claimed the handset would include a top-notch camera, a flexible display and revolutionary software features, however most specs have remained a mystery. According to a report from Android World, the flagship smartphone will be equipped with a 4.7-inch full HD display, a quad-core Tegra 4i processor and a 16-megapixel camera. The device will also reportedly include the latest version of Android, rumored to be called Key Lime Pie, and a 5-megapixel front-facing camera with eye scrolling technology. Purported dimensions are said to be 131.2 x 66.7 x 7.9 mm, making the device slightly thinner than the DROID RAZR MAXX HD.

Topic.Title: INTC is the new #1 shorted stock on the NASDAQ

Message.Msg: I am a long term investor so I am not really normally caught up in the quarter over quarter reports but I don't think I have every been more bullish on a quarter. Expectations for this quarter are very low. I think too low. It would be very hard for INTC to disappoint anyone. The trader in me say this is a good setup. Post earnings the downside risk is 22 and the upside is for it to test 26. I bought some trading shares around 23, couldn't help myself. I am willing to risk a point of downside for 3 points of upside any day of the week.

Topic.Title: Didn't Intel buy a big number of Patents from Motorolla?

Message.Msg: Motorola's CEO all but confirmed the X phone will have an arm cpu: from phandroid: Talking more about Moto X, it seems Motorola will once again be placing their focus on their “Smart Actions, with Woodside saying the device will be “contextually aware” and “anticipate” the user’s needs by utilizing various low power sensors. When going into the manufacturing process, Woodside revealed that the Moto X will actually be built here in the US — Fort Worth, Texas, specifically — something you just don’t see from smartphone manufacturers who typically outsource the building of their devices to overseas manufacturers like Foxconn. While around 70% of the device will be built here in the US, he went on to clarify that system components like the OLED display and CPU will be built in Korea and Taiwan, respectively. However, there are other devices coming from Motorola and Intel might be inside one of them from theverge Details are still relatively scarce, though Woodside did cite breakability and battery life as two of the things Larry Page is most focused on, which dovetails nicely with what we've heard before about Motorola's plans. Motorola's also apparently working with a number of different carriers, and Woodside said "the response has been great." The phone's coming by October, along with "a handful" of other devices.

Message.Title: Why is the PC market being cannibalized? Who will benefit most as a result?
Message.Msg: Q: Why is the PC market being cannibalized? A: There are many people who do not need heavy-duty PC compute power on a daily basis. What they really need is a light-weight laptop or even table to satisfy their daily web browsing, email or media consumption needs. For them, lower cost laptops or tablets will surface. Of course there is also a segment of users that need a main PC to do heavy lifting such as video editing, work-related productivity work, etc. This segment will not go away any time soon. Many will just keep refreshing one main PC + one or two tablets. Q: Who will benefit as a result of this PC-cannibalization? A: Think of why people dump PC. They want to do daily browsing, email with a piece of cheap hardware. Introducing to you Samsung Ativ Q and Asus Transformer Book Trio. These are tables, with attachable keyboard. They are also "laptop". They can dual-boot Window 8 and Android. Besides the usually web-browsing and emailing, you can perform the usual Window productivity works, as well as downloading and running Android apps. You can even launch Android apps from the Window 8 tiles. This kind of dual-OS, hybrid "lapblet" will be the future. This segment will capture a large portion of the users that had “dumped” or are planing to "dump" the PC. The initial versions of these "lapblets" will be expensive. But thanks to competition, over time the prices of these "lapblets" will come down to $300 - $400 range, comparable to the mid-tier tablets today, since the added complexity is quite minimal. Now my question is: with this new and growing segment, who will stand to benefit the most? Let's see. Intel has tons of experience with Window. It is now entering Android and picking up pace (Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 and many other design wins for Android). Beside Intel, who else is better position to capture this market? Hint: The Arm-based Window RT is a disaster.

Message.Title: Scoop: Intel’s upcoming TV service is going to be called OnCue
Message.Msg: Intel’s TV service, which the company’s Intel Media unit plans to launch before the end of the year, is going to be called OnCue, GigaOM has learned. The company has applied for trademarks for OnCue around the globe and tasked ad agency OMD to prepare the official introduction of the brand. Intel is planning to launch a TV service before the end of the year that is meant to compete with traditional cable TV services by offering live TV feeds as well as a catch-up service and on-demand programming. The service will be available through a dedicated device, which the company is going to sell online as well as through traditional retailers. Intel hasn’t revealed the name of the offering yet, but the company has been quietly preparing to launch it under the OnCue brand. from gigaom

Topic.Title: Scoop: Intel’s upcoming TV service is going to be called OnCue

Message.Msg: from pcmag: Sest has "also been busy filing a number of trademark applications outside of the U.S., including in Canada, Mexico, and Europe, the site reported. The attorney retained in Europe to file a Sest trademark application "has also filed numerous other Intel trademarks in the past, including the original Intel Inside filing," GigaOM added. [Looks like Intel TV is going global]

Message.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark
Message.Msg: Technical consulting firm BDTI pointed out that the compiled code for the Intel processor was not executing all instructions that were intended for the RAM test. This artificially improved the results for the Lenovo K900 smartphone and the Intel Atom processors.

Topic.Title: Why is the PC market being cannibalized? Who will benefit most as a result?

Message.Msg: Recap: the Samsung ATIV Q Lapblet - can be a tablet or a "laptop" with a detachable keyboard - can dual-boot Window 8 and Android - can run 700,000 Android apps and 50,000 Window apps - can launch Android from Window 8 tile screen - can easily share files and data between Android and Window 8 OS - with sideSync software, you can share data, screen, mouse, keyboard between your "lapblet" and your mobile devices. Goto youtube and search for: "[Samsung ATIV] SideSync Introduction" - Samsung ATIV Q is rated for 9 hours

Topic.Title: Why is the PC market being cannibalized? Who will benefit most as a result?

Message.Msg: Sorry typo: "detachable keyboard" should have read "foldable keyboard". Also, you can run Window app and Android app side by side.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: Lenovo K900 uses Intel Clovertrail+ (Saltwell), not the Intel's upcoming Bay Trail (Silvermont). Bay Trail beats Arm best Soc in power and performance by wide margin.

Message.Title: Amazon shaves $200 off Macbook Air models, hits top spot in sales
Message.Msg: The Macbook Air continues to be a hit with consumers, promising a battery-life that could outdo even the best competitors on the market. Now you can pick up an upgraded model, for the base-model price thanks to a promotion on Amazon. Apple sells an 11″ $999 model for the latest Macbook Air but that is the base installation, with (1.3GHz dual-core Intel Core i5 processor, Intel HD Graphics 5000, 4GB memory, 128GB flash storage) but starting today the 13″ Macbook Air model on Amazon for $999 comes with (2.5 GHz Dual-Core Intel Core i5, 4 GB, 500 GB Hard Drive and Intel HD Graphics 4000). So you are trading the latest video card for an incredible boost in capacity. There are a few other combinations that you can create with the deal, a 13″ with 750GB of storage is also $200 off for a limited time and the 15″ model with 500GB of storage comes with the NVIDIA GeForce GT 650M 1GB Graphics card. That model is currently $100 off for a limited time. The 13″ Macbook jumped to the number 2 spot in Amazon’s (Best Sellers Electronics : Notebooks) division, showing that customers are quick to pounce when Macs go on sale, though it still is rather rare. from theslanted
